About Us

MLST

MLST is a tool that will run input genomes against PubMLST schemes and output the scheme most closely matching the input genome along with the alleles used to select the scheme.

Inputs: fasta or Genbank sequencing files. If your raw data is in fastq format, it is advised that the data be run through an assembler, such as Skesa to both improve quality and put the data in assembled, fasta format.

Output: A single tabular data file containing the filenames of your input files, the scheme found to match each input file, and the alleles used to match the scheme to the input.


For the purposes of this tutorial, it is assumed that the user has previously created a history, uploaded fastq or fasta files, and run an assembler such as Skesa. If you need help with the history and file import would like to learn more about those steps, please visit this tutorial for help with histories and this tutorial for fastq inport.

Once you have your assembled data in your history, search for MLST in the search tools bar and select the MLST tool.

Input either the multiple datasets containing your FASTA files or a collection of such files. Note that when the multiple datasets option is used, each sequence to be filtered must be selected as if selecting multiple files in Windows (hold down the ctrl key and click on items in the list individually or hold down the shift key and highlight the last item in a group to be selected).

If you do not desire to specify advanced parameters, click Execute to run the tool. If you have reason to believe you need to alter the default parameters for your particular use case, feel free to reach out to us at microseqtrain@fda.hhs.gov if you have any questions about doing so.


Documentation for MLST can be found at these locations:

  • T, S. (2016). MLST: Scan contig files against PubMLST typing schemes.
  • bio.tools
  • OpenEBench

Click to watch the video walkthrough


The video tutorial started with a collection of 10 GenomeTrakr Validation Strain Set sequence pairs that had been run through Skesa. To follow along, begin by importing these same files from NCBI by downloading this txt file containing the list of SRR accessions for the 10 sequences, uploading the file into GalaxyTrakr and using it to import the sequencing data from NCBI (see this tutorial for assistance), and running Skesa on the resulting collection of sequences.

This file contains the output from running MLST on the Skesa results.
